title: 111_hr3737
content: The "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009" allows intermediaries to report borrower information to credit agencies for credit building. It also provides flexibility in credit terms for small businesses. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from certain paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have specific experience and qualifications, including at least 1 year of experience in making microloans or having a full-time employee with 3 years of experience in making microloans. Additionally, they must have experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance as part of their microloan program. The Small Business Act now requires individuals involved in making microloans to have specific experience and qualifications, including at least 1 year of experience in providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing to $1,000,000 and $7,000,000, with the option to treat it as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage to 35%. SEC. 7 introduces the Young Entrepreneurs Program. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program, allowing intermediaries to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing small businesses and acquiring financing. The Young Entrepreneurs Program allows intermediaries to provide technical assistance to young entrepreneurs aged 25 or younger who have resided in the area for at least 2 years. Young entrepreneurs receiving assistance must make a good faith effort to establish or operate their small business in the same geographic area. Repayment on loans for small businesses operated by young entrepreneurs may be deferred. Repayment on loans for small businesses operated by young entrepreneurs may be deferred for up to 6 months after receiving the final disbursement of the loan. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the microloan program. The Administrator must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business, detailing the names and locations of intermediaries receiving funds, loan and grant amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and the number and amounts of microloans made. The microloan program under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act now requires a report detailing the intermediaries receiving funds, loan amounts, contributions from non-Federal sources, and microloans made to various groups such as women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The microloan program under Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act now requires a report on the performance of intermediaries, including job creation, repayment history, and success of businesses receiving microloans. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers receiving financing under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and 2011 totaling $200 million for technical assistance grants, direct loans, and interest assistance grants under section 7(m) of the Small Business Act. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions. Passed the House of Representatives on November 7, 2009.
